title: 10 Minutes a Day: What Parents Should Actually Do During Math Time
description: A minute-by-minute guide to making the most of short daily math practice sessions.
imageAlt: Parent and child during 10-minute math session

content.intro: You've committed to 10 minutes of daily math practice. Now what? Here's exactly what those 10 minutes should look like – for you and your child.

rows: Ensures device is ready, says "Let's go!"
Closes app, reports how it went

items: **During:** Be present (same room), not hovering (not watching every problem)
**After:** Brief encouragement, move on with the day

sections.text: If you're actively teaching or correcting during these 10 minutes, you're doing too much. The app teaches; you provide the structure.
What to Do with Your 8 "Free" Minutes
Just stay in the same room. Your presence matters without your attention on every problem.

items: "Ready? Let's see what level you get today."
"It's okay to get some wrong – that's how you learn."
"What level did you reach?" (if they want to share)

sections.text: Stop. Even mid-problem. This is crucial. Why?

items: It teaches them to focus (limited time = urgency)
It prevents practice from dragging on
It leaves them wanting a bit more (positive association)
It builds trust (10 minutes means 10 minutes)
Asking what felt easy or hard

faq.question: What if they finish early?
faq.answer: Great! They can stop early or do a bonus challenge. Don't force them to fill time. Finishing early = reward for efficiency.

faq.question: What if 10 minutes isn't enough for their homework?
faq.answer: The 10 minutes is for skill practice, not homework completion. Homework is separate. But consistent practice makes homework faster over time.

faq.question: Should I review what they did?
faq.answer: A quick glance at the progress report is fine. Don't go through every problem. Trust the app's feedback system.

cta.text: SoroKid is designed for 10-15 minute sessions – the perfect daily practice.
